Authors:
Prashant S Gaikwad, Swanand S Joshi, Smita S Zinjarde,
Ameeta Ravikumar
Title:
Molecular and Genomic Analysis of the marine strain Yarrowia
lipolytica NCIM 3590 suggests it canbe reclassified as Y.bubula NCIM
3590.
Keywords:
Yarrowia bubula, molecular identification, phylogeny,
whole genome sequencing, dDDH, ANI
Abstract:
The Yarrowia clade contains species morphologically,
ecologically, physiologically and genetically diverse in nature. The
strain, Y.lipolytica NCIM 3590 (Yl3590), isolated from Scottish sea
waters was reinvestigated for its phenotypic, molecular and genomic
properties as it exhibited characteristics unlike Y.lipolytica, namely,
growth at low temperatures (10-20°C) and absence of extracellular
lipolytic activity. Preliminary studies based on colony/cellular
morphology, effect of temperature/salt on growth, sugar assimilation and
fermentation tests were inconclusive to ascertain the identity of the
strain. Hence, molecular identification was performed using ITS and
D1/D2 sequences and BLAST analysis suggeststhatYl3590is 100% identical
to Y.bubula NCAIM Y.01998 and Y.bubula CBS 12934. Phylogenetic analysis
with reference Yarrowia sequences reported in the NCBI database revealed
thatYl3590 clustered with Y.bubula under a separate node. Additionally,
to corroborate the results, whole genome sequencing using IIlumina
NextSeq technology was performed and we report here the first draft
genome of this strain. The genomic relatedness of Yl3590 was determined
with the available reference genome sequences of Y.bubula CBS 12934 as
well as Y.lipolytica CLIB 89 andCLIB122 using genome wide metrics,
digital DNA-DNA hybridization (dDDH) and average nucleotide identity
(ANI). The values obtained for dDDH (94.1%), ANIb/ANIm (99.41/99.42%)and
for Ortho ANI (99.47%) between Yl3590 and Y.bubula were greater than for
Y. lipolytica. These were above the acceptable threshold values (dDDH ≥
70%, ANI/orthoANI ≥ 95-96 %) for species delineation, indicating that
they belong to the same genomic species. Hence, we suggest that Yl3590
could be reclassified as Yarrowia bubula NCIM 3590.
